title.narrative: Building Bridges for Women's Economic Empowerment

description.narrative: - Greater cross-sector coherence on the definition of WEE, the business case for WEE, and approaches to WEE programming - Private sector companies are capable and willing to advance women’s rights in global value chains - Women’s Funds and Women’s Rights Organisations (WF/WROs) deliver localised WEE programming through cross-sector partnerships

title.narrative: Thought piece - women's economic resilience in Kenya's flower sector

description.narrative: As a result of the Knowledge Partnership focusing on rebuilding Kenya's floriculture sector post covid-19 with a gender lens (note: this is the final version but is yet to be designed. It will be shared on social media in February 2021).

title.narrative: Thought piece - impact of COVID-19 on women owned businesses in the flower sector
Year 1 Annual Report, 2020
Establishment of a shared definition of WEE and wider agreement on essential elements in WEE strategies and programming
# kickoff meetings (NL, Kenya)

comment.narrative: 1 launch event was held on February 20, 2020 in at Win-Win Strategies' office in Amsterdam, NL. The launch in Kenya was not possible due to COVID-19, however engagement with key stakeholder has progress nevertheless.

title.narrative: # narrative reports of research produced

comment.narrative: 2 articles/thought pieces have been created. 1. Defining women's economic empowerment and resilience - https://www.womenwin.org/win-win/news/opinion/defining-womens-economic-empowerment-and-resilience/ 2. Defining gender due diligence - https://www.womenwin.org/win-win/news/research/gender-responsive-due-diligence-what-is-the-future/

title.narrative: Increased number of WF/WRO designing and delivering corporate engagement strategies
# CFI ToT workshops delivered

comment.narrative: 1 Corporate Engagement Training of Trainers workshop was delivered in Nairobi, Kenya from March 12-13 to one organisation (Eselle Group). Due to COVID-19, the facilitators could not deliver any workshops themselves but in Year 2 of the program they will c0deliver the content via a hybrid online facilitator approach.

title.narrative: # organisations trained to deliver CFI workshops

comment.narrative: 1 organisation (Eselle Group) was trained to deliver CFI workshops (March 12-13, Nairobi)

title.narrative: # ToT workshop toolkit designed

comment.narrative: 1 workshop toolkit has been created in order to support the Training of Trainers for the Corporate Engagement course (previously CFI). This includes an agenda, activities, roles played and slide content.

title.narrative: # of WF/WRO-delivered workshops

comment.narrative: This could no longer take place in Year due to the corona crisis. This activity will be picked up again in Year 2.

title.narrative: Consolidated and expanded evidence-base demonstrating the business case for WEE programming formulated in a coherent and comprehensible manner suited for the private sector
# case studies conducted, reported and shared

comment.narrative: As we could not action the corporate engagement components of the project, we repurposed these funds to produce additional thought pieces to support corporate thinking on the following topics: 1. Building a better future for women workers in intl product supply chain - https://www.womenwin.org/win-win/news/research/the-due-diligence-framework/ 2. Women's economic resilience in Kenya's flower sector - see attachments (not yet designed) (will be shared on social media in Q1 2021)

title.narrative: Women's funds & women's rights organisations (WF/WROs) have improved knowledge and skills in partnering with the corporate sector
# Collaborating for Impact (CFI) workshops delivered

comment.narrative: Due to the pandemic no workshops were delivered in Year 1. Instead we adapted the workshop content for an online course. There is 3+ hours of recorded facilitation by WWS staff, 2 hours of interviews with women's rights organisations and companies around the world, as well as downloadable tools to guide participants through partnerships with the corporate sector. The course is self-paced and will be launched in Year 2 as we kick off a hybrid self pace + webinar approach to the course. The course can be found here - https://womenwinlearninglab.thinkific.com/courses/corporate-engagement-course

title.narrative: x% of participants report an increase in knowledge and skills in partnering with the corporate sector post-CFI workshop
# representatives of WF/WROs participated
Greater use of evidence in cross-sector WEE programming in value chains
Online open-source platform created

comment.narrative: This project has helped to create a more user friendly and reflective website for the work of WWS (https://www.womenwin.org/win-win/). This project has it's own page and links to the many resources that have been produced under this program (publications: https://www.womenwin.org/win-win/news/) and (online workshop course: https://womenwinlearninglab.thinkific.com/courses/corporate-engagement-course)

title.narrative: Increased number of champions within companies with knowledge of, and ability to use, holistic WEE, women-centered design strategies
# of toolkits developed (1. How to incorporate a building-block, 2. Women-centered approach to WEE programs)

comment.narrative: Albeit facing some delay in launching due to re-organising activities and the program strategy in the height of COVID-19, we will launch our first "tool" in the form of a platform. The objective is to support companies adopt a gender lens when conducting due diligence. We have gathered the best tools and recommendations in order to create the "go-to" place for companies interested in developing here.

title.narrative: # champions within companies report an increase in knowledge of, and the ability to use, holistic WEE, women-centered design strategies
# representatives of companies participated in BBWs
# Bridge-Builders Workshops (BBW) delivered

comment.narrative: We had intended to host 1 BBW in Year 1 but this was not possible due to the corona virus. During the height of the pandemic, companies' sole focus was on survival. We respect that and therefore aimed to repurpose the funds to support gender/women's empowerment in other ways. A key activity was a Knowledge Partnership made up of a women's rights organizations with expertise in Kenya's floriculture sector. We hosted 4 Knowledge Exchanges during we solution-driven conversations were held in order to rebuild the sector in a way that is more supportive of it's female workers. This activity was a huge success and will carry forth into Year 2 programming.

title.narrative: Companies from three industries in the Netherlands have the tools and knowledge to apply a gender lens in their due diligence process and have the ability to use holistic WEE design strategies in their value chains
# gender lens tools tested and shared on open source platform

comment.narrative: Our gender-responsive due diligence platform will go live on March 8.

title.narrative: # Equileap ranking reports published and events held

comment.narrative: The first report launch was held in October 2020 however an event was not possible due to covid-19. Find report here - https://equileap.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Equileap_DutchReport.pdf

title.narrative: Increased number of companies in key geographies having an improved understanding of the role of holistic building block approaches to WEE and benefits of female leaders and entrepreneurs across value chains
# companies show greater understanding of and/or apply gender-focused procurement practices
# champions within companies with knowledge of, and the ability to use, holistic WEE, women-centered design strategies
# of companies engaged that report having an improved understanding of the importance or value-add of cross-sector partnerships and knowledge of the role of holistic building block approaches to WEE
